questions.text: A person is accused of committing Rape. He claims to be adolescent. He is brought to the government hospital for age estimation to determine if he should be sent to juvenile home or an adult jail. The X-ray image of the pelvis is shown below. What is the age?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 17-18 years

 

  • Head, greater trochanter, and lesser trochanter are all fused with the shaft of femur (so age > 17 years)
  • Iliac crest is not yet fused (so age < 18 years)
  • Hence, age is 17-18 years.

 

Core Concept

 

Femur

Head – 1 yr (A)                         

Greater Trochanter- 4 yr (A)

Lesser trochanter – 14 yr (A)              fuse with shaft at 17- 19 yrs of age

 

Pelvis

 

 

 

Other Options are self explanatory from the explanation above

questions.text: Area covered under the two ‘Points of Inflection’ in the Normal distribution curve is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 68%

  • In a normal distribution curve (also known as a Gaussian distribution or bell curve), the area covered under the two 'points of inflection' is approximately 68% of the total area under the curve.
  • The points of inflection on a normal distribution curve are the points where the curve changes from top convex part to concave parts on the sides. These points are located at one standard deviation below the mean and one standard deviation above the mean.

choices.text: "Res Ipsa Loquitur"

questions.text:
In a complex medical malpractice lawsuit, Amit, a 40-year-old patient, underwent a routine laparoscopic cholecystectomy at a reputable hospital. The surgery was performed by Dr. Sheela, a highly skilled surgeon. However, during the procedure, an unforeseen event occurred. Amit sustained a deep laceration to her abdominal aorta, a major blood vessel, which required immediate vascular surgery to repair.

 

Despite the seriousness of the injury, Amit's legal team encountered difficulties in identifying the precise cause of the aortic laceration or pinpointing a specific act of negligence. There were no clear breaches of established surgical protocols, and Dr. Sheela's credentials and experience were impeccable.

 

In the context of this challenging case, which legal doctrine might Amit's legal team invoke to establish negligence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. "Res Ipsa Loquitur"

 

Injury to abdominal aorta is not an expected complication of cholecystectomy. It is so obvious that surgeon would have been grossly negligent, only than the aorta could have been injured in this case. Since the negligence is obvious, the legal doctrine of "res ipsa loquitur" may be invoked.

 

Core Concept

 

Res ipsa loquitur:

  • It is a Latin phrase for "the thing speaks for itself."
  • Common knowledge Doctrine: Negligence is so obvious that it does not require expert testimony or specific evidence to establish a breach of the standard of care.
  • Obvious Negligence: The event is unusual and wouldn't occur without negligence
  • The defendant had control over the situation or object that caused the injury.
  • The plaintiff didn't contribute to the injury.

 

Other Options

 

Option A) "Respondeat Superior": It is a legal doctrine that holds employers liable for the actions of their employees if those actions occur within the scope of employment.

 

B) "Res Judicata": It is a legal principle that prevents the same matter or claim from being litigated again after it has already been adjudicated by a competent court.

 

D) "Res Gestae": It refers to statements or acts that are so closely associated with a particular event that they are considered part of the event itself. It is not directly related to establishing negligence in medical malpractice cases.

choices.text: JNA arises from posterior pharyngeal wall
JNA arises from sphenopalatine foramen
JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin
JNA do not have muscular contractile part in its blood vessels

questions.text: Dodd sign is absent in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma because?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin

 

Explanation – JNA arises from sphenopalatine foramen and spreads submucosally towards posterior pharyngeal wall side as well as towards the pterygopalatine fossa side. In the submucosal space of posterior pharyngeal space, this tumour enlarges and bulges forwards. Hence, there won’t be any Dodd sign here. Even though b and d options are correct, they do not justify the absence of Dodd sign.

choices.text: MALA N contains 60 mg Ferrous fumarate
CuT 375 has a shelf life of 4-5 years
ANTARA leads to irregular cycles
CHHAYA should be taken 1 tablet a week since start

questions.text: Find the Incorrect statement about Contraceptives used in RCH program?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CHHAYA should be taken 1 tablet a week since start

  • MALA N contains 30 mcg Ethinyl estardiol, 150 mcg LNG and 60 mg Ferrous fumarate
  • CuT 375 has a shelf life of 4-5 years (CuT 380 A has shelf life of 10 years)
  • ANTARA (DMPA – Depot Medroxy Progesterone Acetate) is an Injectable hormonal contraceptive (Depot formulation) which leads to irregular cycles
  • CHHAYA (older name Saheli – Centchroman) is a safe spacing option for both breast feeding and non-breast feeding women and needs to be taken only twice a week for the first 3 months and then once a week thereafter

questions.text: Following is NOT used a diagnostic test used under National TB Elimination Program of India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Serological diagnosis (IgG, IgM)

  • The Government of India issued Gazette notification vide 433E, 7th June 2012 has banned the manufacture, importation, distribution and use of currently available commercial serological tests for diagnosing TB. These tests are not recommended for diagnosis of TB
  • There is no role for inaccurate / inconsistent diagnostics like serology (IgM, IgG, IgA antibodies against MTB antigens- these serological tests are banned in India), various in-house or non-validated commercial PCR tests and BCG test.

questions.text: Which amongst the following you would not need for calculations in Cataract patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Corneal Thickness

questions.text: A forensic investigator is examining a series of bruises on a victim's body. To determine whether these bruises are artificial or true bruises, which of the following characteristics would be most useful to assess?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Color changes over time

 

In true bruises, the color of the bruise evolves in a characteristic pattern, starting with a reddish appearance that gradually changes to blue, purple, green, yellow, and finally fades away. This is due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and the absorption of blood pigments by different cellular components. Artificial bruises, on the other hand, might not follow this natural progression and may exhibit inconsistent color changes.

 

Core Concept

 

 

Other options

 

B) Size of the bruise: The size of a bruise can provide some information about its cause. Generally, larger bruises are more likely to be associated with trauma. However, artificial bruises can also be intentionally created in various sizes.

 

C) Presence of underlying bone fractures: Fractures can contribute to the development of bruises, especially in true bruises resulting from trauma. However, fractures are not always necessary for bruising to occur. Artificial bruises can be inflicted without causing fractures, and some fractures might not lead to noticeable bruising.

 

D) Victim's medical history: While certain medical conditions can contribute to the development of bruises, both true and artificial bruises can occur regardless of the victim's medical history.

choices.text: Metal fume fever

questions.text: A welder presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, headache, fatigue, and muscle aches after working with galvanized steel for several hours. The place of work is poorly ventilated. On physical examination, his vital signs are stable, and there are no specific findings on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Metal fume fever

 

Metal fume fever is caused by inhaling metal oxide fumes (especially Zinc, Aluminium and Magnesium), during welding or similar processes. Symptoms described in question are characteristic of metal fume fever and consistent with patient's work environment.

 

Core Concept

 

Metal fume fever:

  1. Also known as brass shakes,[zinc shakes, or metal dust fever)
  2. It is caused by exposure to chemicals such as zinc (most common), aluminum, or magnesium which are produced as byproducts in the fumes that result when certain metals are heated.
  3. Welders are commonly exposed to the substances that cause metal fume fever.
  4. Clinical features are flu-like or malaria-like. They include fever, chills, headache, fatigue, muscle aches, joint pains, shortness of breath, pneumonia, chest pain etc. Flu-like symptoms normally disappear within 24 to 48 hours.

Mnemonic: ZAM causes metal fume fever (Z for Zinc, A for aluminium, M for magnesium)

 

Other Options

 

Option a) Pneumonia: Pneumonia can result in symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, fatigue, and muscle aches. While this is a possibility, the fact that symptoms occurred after working with galvanized steel suggests another diagnosis is more likely.

 

Option b) Tuberculosis: It can lead to fever, fatigue, and other systemic symptoms. However, TB is less likely in this scenario because the symptoms are closely related to the exposure to galvanized steel.

 

Option d) Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling crystalline silica dust. It leads to coughing, shortness of breath, and other respiratory symptoms. While exposure to metal dust is a concern for workers in metal fabrication, the symptoms described in the question are not typical of silicosis.

choices.text: Right medial rectus recession and left lateral rectus recession
Left lateral rectus recession and medial rectus recession
Left lateral rectus resection and medial rectus recession

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient presents to your clinic with complaints of inward deviation of the left eye that has been there since past 10 years. Visual acuity in both eyes is 20/20, and there are no signs of amblyopia. On examination, you note a left compensatory face turn and on doing a PBCT a deviation measuring 30 prism diopters is noted. The alternate cover test confirms this measurement. What is the appropriate surgical correction for this patient's left eye strabismus ?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Left lateral rectus resection and medial rectus recession

choices.text: Transformer ratio is decreased after surgery
Stapedial reflex is intact after surgery
The contents of the middle ear that are modified in this surgery develop from 1st pharyngeal arch

questions.text: A patient presented with right sided hardness of hearing. Otoendoscopy and pure tone audiometry were given below. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the condition in this patient ?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Surgery is contraindicated

 

Explanation – The presence of schwartz sign in the otoendoscopy picture shows that the otosclerosis is active. Hence, the surgery is contraindicated. (If surgery is attempted, there will be more bleed due to the active disease process and increased vascularity.)

 

Transformer ratio increases because the diameter of the piston will be around 0.8mm. Hence areal ratio (45mm2 / 0.8mm2) will be increased 4 times when compared to normal areal ratio (45mm2 / 3.2mm2). Lever ratio remains same.

 

As stapedius tendon is cut during surgery, stapedial reflex is lost after surgery.

 

The contents of the middle ear that are modified in this surgery develop from 2nd pharyngeal arch. Stapes suprastructure (which develops from 2nd arch) is removed. Stapedius tendon (which belongs to 2nd arch) is cut.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a history of open-angle glaucoma. Despite using prostaglandin analogs and beta-blockers, their intraocular pressure (IOP) remains elevated. Which of the following medications should be considered as an adjunctive therapy in this case?
questions.solution: Ans C. Rho kinase inhibitors

questions.text: Cobalt therapy units in Indian Medical Colleges were introduced with the support of
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Colombo plan

  • Cobalt-60 (Co-60) therapy units were introduced as part of efforts to improve cancer treatment facilities in India. Cobalt-60 is a radioactive isotope of cobalt that emits high-energy gamma rays, which can be used for radiation therapy to treat cancer.
  • The introduction of Cobalt therapy units in Indian medical colleges, supported by the Colombo Plan, played a crucial role in enhancing cancer treatment capabilities in the country.

questions.text: A Pregnant woman in third trimester complains of hearing her own sounds. Examination of the ear shows movements of tympanic membrane synchronous with respiration and especially exaggerated when nostril on the contralateral side is occluded. Your diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Patulous Eustachian tube

 

Eustachian tube lies closed most of the time. Opens during yawning, swallowing, chewing, etc., with the help of muscles like tensor veli palatini, levator veli palatini and salpingopharyngeus.

 

Instead, if Eustachian tube stays constantly open, then that condition is called as patulous Eustachian tube. Here, the patient will hear his own voice (autophony), his own breath sounds. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane movements can be seen synchronised with inspiration (inward) and expiration (outward). Few causes include rapid weight loss, 3rd trimester of pregnancy, multiple sclerosis. No treatment required for acute cases. Weight gain, oral KI can be given. Cauterisation of ET or grommet insertion can be planned in chronic cases.

questions.text:

  1. Benefit measured in terms of natural units-Cost benefit analysis
  2. Method based on behavioral sciences-MBO
  3. PERT-Network Analysis
  4. Benefit measured in terms of QALY-Cost effective analysis
questions.solution: Ans. B. 2,3,4

choices.text: Maximum Demographic gap is seen in the Early Stage 3
It is based on Annual growth rate of a country
Total population consistently increase from Stage 1 through end of Stage 5

questions.text: Correct statement about Demographic cycle is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Demographic transition model has 4 stages

  • Demographic gap (DG) is based on Crude birth rate and Crude death rate
  • Maximum DG is seen in the Late Stage 2
  • Population increases from Stage 1 through Stage 4 but then declines in Stage 5
  • Demographic transition model has 4 stages (corresponding to the first 4 stages of Demographic cycle): 1 – Pre-industrial; 2 – Urbanising/ Industrial; 3 – Mature industrial; 4 – Post-industrial.

questions.solution: Ans. C. Fundus Fluoroscein Angiography

choices.text: Radius of Inner circle is 1.5 R
Radius of Outer circle is 3.5 R
Blades are separated by 45 degrees each
Its original version was blue colour set on a magenta background

questions.text: True about the Logo/symbol shown below is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radius of Inner circle is 1.5 R

  • In 1946, the ionising radiation trefoil started as a ‘doodle’ produced by a group of people at the Berkeley Radiation Laboratory, University of California, who were keen to develop a warning symbol for this new kind of dangerous material. 
  • At the time, it was rendered as magenta, and was set on a blue background. The trefoil is now black in the international version.
  • The radioactive symbol itself is drawn with a central circle of radius R, an internal radius of 1.5R and an external radius of 5R for the blades, which are separated from each other by 60 degrees

questions.text: During live presentation of Dr Apurv’s class there is a sudden blackout. Mrs Jagruti Walia - the head of Ops team immediately sends for a backup generator. During connecting the generator a 35-year-old worker gets accidental exposure to a petrochemical substance resulting in severe eye pain and blurred vision. On examination, his affected eye appears red and edematous. Immediately in-house ophthalmologist Dr Gaurav is called upon, you are an intern accompanying him. Which of the following you would DEFINITELY NOT see Dr Gaurav doing during the treatment of the patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Patching the eye with pad and Bandage to provide relief

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with decreased hearing on right side. You have done tuning fork tests and found that Rinne was negative on right side and Weber lateralised to the right ear. Otoendoscopy picture is shown below. Where do you expect the primary pathology? Find the relevant picture in the given options.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. None of the above

 

Explanation – Otoendoscopy shows serous otitis media. Unilateral SOM in a 60-year-old can be suspected of having nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Hence nasopharynx should be checked for the primary pathology. But, in this question, patient was having right SOM. So, the primary pathology should be checked on right side of nasopharynx. But the picture given in c option is of left nasopharynx. Hence d is the right option.

questions.text: Incorrect combination about Instruments used in Public Health and their use is
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Horrock’s apparatus – Residual chlorine level

  • Horrock's apparatus is used for calculation of amount of bleaching powder needed for purification of water (Chlorine demand estimation)
  • Chloroscope is used to assess Free/Residual chlorine level in water

choices.text: Strength of association in an epidemiological study design
Intention to treat trial in RCT

questions.text: The following graph is used to assess.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Publication bias in meta-analysis

  • A funnel plot is a graph designed to check for the existence of publication bias; funnel plots are commonly used in systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
  • Asymmetry in the funnel plot, measured using regression analysis, is an indication of publication bias. In the absence of bias, results from small studies will scatter widely at the bottom of the graph, with the spread narrowing among larger studies

choices.text: III, IV, V, VI & VII
All waves will be absent

questions.text: A patient has undergone a procedure that is shown in the following picture. BERA test was done after the procedure (sound stimulus was directly given from outside to the processor instead of giving through earphone in ear canal). Which waves will be found abnormal?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. I & II

 

Explanation – The picture shows Auditory brainstem implant. It will be done in cases of auditory neuropathy. Pre-operative BERA will show no responses because the sound wave cannot travel through auditory nerve and hence the brainstem nuclei cannot get stimulated. So, all waves will be absent.

 

After ABSI, the sound waves will directly reach the brainstem bypassing the auditory nerve. Hence the waves corresponding to brainstem nuclei and central cortex (III to VII) will be present. The waves related to eighth nerve will be absent (I & II).

questions.text: The formula given by: True positives / (True positives + False Positives) X 100 represents?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. PPV

  • Positive Predictive Value (PPV) is a statistical metric used in binary classification (such as medical testing, diagnostic tests, or machine learning) to measure the proportion of true positive predictions out of all positive predictions made
  • It represents diagnostic power of a screening test

questions.text: Which of the following method of health communication is didactic in nature?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Chalk and talk method

  • A lecture (Chalk and talk method) is often considered Didactic (One way communication) because it is a teaching method that is structured to convey information or knowledge in a one-way communication format, where the lecturer imparts knowledge to the audience, typically without active participation or interaction from the audience.
  • Focus group discussion, Symposium, and Interpersonal communication are Socratic (Two way) methods of health communication

choices.text: The accused cannot invoke Section 84 since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication.
Section 84 applies as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence
Section 84 is inapplicable due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms
The accused can only invoke Section 84 if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness

questions.text: A 30-year-old individual diagnosed with schizophrenia commits an act that would otherwise be considered a criminal offense. The act was committed during a period of acute psychotic episode. The individual's medical history indicates sporadic adherence to prescribed antipsychotic medication. The prosecution has charged the individual with the offense. Based on the provided information, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the applicability of Section 84 of IPC in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Section 84 applies as the offence was committed during psychotic episode, regardless of medication adherence.

 

Core Concept:

 

Section 84 IPC: Act of a person of unsound mind

 

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

 

Section 84 of the IPC provides a legal defense for individuals who commit an offense while they are of unsound mind. In this case, the individual has been diagnosed with schizophrenia, a recognized serious mental disorder. However, whether the accused was truly of unsound mind at the time of the offense would depend on the severity of the symptoms during that period, which in this case was indeed severe (an acute psychotic episode).

 

Other Options

 

 a) The accused cannot invoke Section 84 since the act was committed while not adhering to prescribed medication. The adherance to medication is not required in 84 IPC

 

c) Section 84 is inapplicable due to the sporadic nature of the individual's symptoms. At the time of commission of offence the victim should be of unsound mind for 84 IPC. In this case then victim had psychotic episode during crime.

 

d) The accused can only invoke Section 84 if the act was committed during a state of complete unconsciousness. Unsoundness of mind is required, not unconsciousness.

choices.text: Medical institutions can only be held responsible for the actions of their employed medical professionals if institution had direct knowledge of the negligence.
Vicarious liability does not apply when medical professionals commit gross negligence, as such actions are considered beyond the scope of their employment.
Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution
Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved had a valid license to practice.

questions.text: In the realm of medical practice, the principle of vicarious liability plays a crucial role in determining legal responsibility. Which of the following statements best exemplifies the concept of vicarious liability in cases of medical negligence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution

 

In the context of medical negligence, vicarious liability means that a healthcare institution, such as a hospital or clinic, can be held legally responsible for the actions or omissions of its medical professionals if those actions occurred within the scope of their employment. This holds true even if the institution itself did not directly contribute to the negligence.

 

While it's more common to apply vicarious liability to employees, there are situations where independent contractors can also trigger vicarious liability, especially if they are integrated into the institution's operations to a significant extent.

 

Other Options

  1. Vicarious liability is not dependent on institution's knowledge of negligence. Employer can be held responsible for the actions of their employees or agents (within the scope of their employment), regardless of the employer's knowledge of those actions.
  2. Vicarious liability applies as long as negligent actions occurred within the scope of employment, irrespective of whether the negligence is considered "gross" or not. Nature of negligence, whether ordinary or gross, does not matter for applying vicarious liability.
  3. Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved had a valid license to practice.
    Possession of a valid license doesn't exempt medical institutions from vicarious liability. Even if a licensed professional commits negligence, the principle of vicarious liability can still hold the employer liable for the actions of their employee or agent.

Due to her poor socio-economic status, the health care provider suggests the OCPs available free of cost under NFWP. What is the composition of the OCP?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Ethinyl estradiol 0.03 mg, Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg, Fe fumarate 60mg
